document.docAuthor: Rodrigues, Henrique Miranda & Cancello, Eliana Marques
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of Stagmatoptera Burmeister, 1838 (Mantodea: Mantidae, Stagmatopterinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic revision of Stagmatoptera Burmeister, 1838 (Mantodea: Mantidae, Stagmatopterinae)

bibRefCitation.author: Beier
bibRefCitation.refString: Beier, M. (1929) Weitere neue Mantiden aus der Sammlung des Naturhistorischen Museums in Wien. Zoologischer Anzeiger, 81 (7 - 10), 245 - 254.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Stagmatoptera hyaloptera ,
Perty, 1832
in Werner, 1925b
, p.382—misidentification (redescr.).
Stagmatoptera reimoseri Beier, 1929
, p. 252 (descr.); Ehrmann, 2002 , p.330 (cit.);
Agudelo et al. , 2007
, p.126 (cit.); Ehrmann & Koçak, 2009 , p.12 (cit.).

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype
: 1♂ , Santa Sofia , Paraguay , 1908, Reimoser leg. ( NHMW ) (examined).

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Spot on the stigma in both sexes with an anterior white spot and two lateral brown spots that may or may not reach each other, prothorax broad and short, forecoxae almost reaching the mesothorax, frontal shield with four carinae in both sexes.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 41.
Stagmatoptera
spp., anterior view of foretibiae (females). A,
Stagmatoptera pia
; B,

; C,

; E,
S .
supplicaria
. Scale bar = 5mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription. Male —Frontal shield with four carinae. ( Fig. 32 D). Prothorax short, broad, lateral margins slightly crenulated on the prozona, smooth on the metazona. Metazona with a weakly marked central keel ( Fig. 34 D). Forecoxae with 5–8 large spines, which alternate with 0–5 smaller spine ( Fig. 36 D). Forefemora elongated and broad, the first three discoidal spines dark on their anterior surface; 14–15 anteroventral spines, usually 15, the first spine and all the big spines dark on the anterior surface, the 10th and the 12th spines may present a small spot of the same coloration on their insertion. Anterior femoral spot extending from the femoral groove to the 8th internal spine, rectangular, an effaced black color that may be a little stronger on the base of the spines ( Fig. 38 D). Foretibiae with 9–11 posteroventral spines, usually 11, and 14–16 anteroventral spines, usually 15; tibial spur green on its anterior surface ( Fig. 40 D). Foretarsi with apical black spots on the anterior surface of the tarsomeres I to IV.

Discoidal area of the forewings with an opaque-green stripe anteriorly, gradually or suddenly becoming hyaline. Spot on the stigma medium sized, with an anterior white spot and two lateral brown spots, posteriorly open. Hindwings hyaline ( Fig. 54 A).

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements . Body length: 60–64.3; head width: 7.7–8.3; prozona length: 4.6–5.2; metazona length: 14.7–16.4; prothorax width: 5.5–6.1; forecoxae length: 11.8–13.8; forefemora length: 14.8–15.8; forefemora width: 3.6–3.9; foretibiae length: 7.9–9.
Ratios . head/prothoracic-width: 1.31–1.4; metazona/prozona: 2.94–3.35; metazona length/prothoracic width: 2.49–2.72; metazona/forecoxae: 1.17–1.25; forefemora length/width: 3.82–4.39.

Female —Frontal shield with four carinae ( Fig. 33 C). Prothorax short, broad, lateral margins slightly crenulated. Metazona with a weakly marked central keel ( Fig. 35 C). Forecoxae with 6–8 large spines, which alternate with 1–12 smaller spine ( Fig. 37 C). Forefemora elongated and broad, the first three discoidal spines dark on their anterior surface; 14–15 anteroventral spines, usually 15, the first spine and all the big spines dark on the anterior surface, the 10th and the 12th spines may present a small spot of the same coloration on their insertion.

Anterior femoral spot extending from the femoral groove to the 8th internal spine, rectangular, an effaced black color ( Fig. 39 C). Foretibiae with 10–12 posteroventral spines, usually 11, and 13–16 anteroventral spines, usually 15; tibial spur green on its anterior surface ( Fig. 41 C). Foretarsi with apical black spots on the anterior surface of tarsomeres I to IV. Spot on the stigma medium sized, with an anterior white spot and two lateral brown spots that do not reach each other posteriorly. Costal area hyaline, discoidal and anal areas hyaline with yellow stripes on the crossveins ( Fig. 54 B).

subSubSection.paragraph: Genitalia . Base of the gonapophysis VIII projecting inwards ( Fig. 49 C); bv roughly triangular ( Fig. 49 C), the inner surface sculpted ( Fig. 50 C); ib sclerotized and sculpted ( Fig. 50 C); pe short, weakly sclerotized, with smooth margins ( Fig. 50 C); gs sclerotized, sculpted ( Fig. 51 C); ls roughly rectangular, posterior process short, conical ( Fig. 51 C).

Measurements . Body length: 58.3–76.6; head width: 8.8–10.7; prozona length: 5.5–6.7; metazona length: 16.1–21.4; prothorax width: 6.8–8.6; forecoxae length: 14.4–19.5; forefemora length: 17.2–21.7; forefemora width: 4.3–5.4; foretibiae length: 8.8–11.8.
Ratios . Head/prothoracic-width: 1.17–1.34; metazona/prozona: 2.76–3.33; metazona length/prothoracic width: 2.26–2.49; metazona/forecoxae: 1.02–1.2; forefemora length/width: 3.82–4.29.

Remarks.
Stagmatoptera reimoseri
was described by Beier (1929) based on a few specimens housed on NHMW collection. A few years earlier Werner (1925) mistakenly identified these same specimens as
S . hyaloptera
.

Distribution. Brazil ( Mato Grosso , Minas Gerais , São Paulo , Tocantins ),
Paraguay
.
Examined material. BRAZIL
: Mato Grosso—Mato Verde, 13.iii.1945 , Raymundo P. Luz, 1♀ , ( MZSP ); Minas Gerais—Lavras, 194?, C. Braga, 1♀ ( MZSP ). Sete Lagoas, iii.1963 , F. Werner, U. Martins & L. Silva, 1♀ ( MZSP ); São Paulo—Botucatu, x.1970 , Abílio col., 1♀ ( MZSP ). Botucatu, iv.1972 , P. Assumpção & A. Clarot, 1♂ ( MZSP ). Botucatu, 12.iii.1980 , R. Carvalho, 1♂ ( MZSP ). Faz. Itaquerê, Nova Europa, 23.iv.1968 , K. Lenko col., 1♂ ( MZSP ). Rio Claro , 25.ii.1943 , Pd. F.S. Pereira col., 1♂ ( MZSP ). S. Paulo, 1♀ ( NHMW ); Tocantins—Miranorte, iv.1965 , L.
